task.title: Task: Creating names
task.shortdesc: In this task, you will learn a few ways to assign names to cells and use them in formulas.

context.p: There are several ways to assign a name to a cell. The method used in practice usually depends on the preferences of the user and their entering speed. In this task, there are two ways proposed to assign a name to a cell and three methods to use the name in a formula.
context.note: The same methods can be used to assign a name to an area of cells.

step.cmd: Enter in A1 the number 100 and in A2 the number 275.
Select A1 and choose Formulas Define Name (group Defined Names) .
step.stepresult:
Dialog box New Name
Dialog box new name
In the Name text box you can enter the name. Sometimes Excel suggests a name. In the Comment box, you can optionally give an explanation, which can be useful later (audits) for checking and creating documentation for the model.

step.cmd: Enter the name Purchases and click on OK.
step.stepresult:
The name box now displays this name instead of the address. Cell A1 with the name Purchases in the name box
Name box with name for cell A1

step.cmd: An alternative and quick way to assign a name is by selecting a cell and then directly enter the name in the name box.

substep.cmd: Click in the name box and change A2 in Sales.

step.cmd: Select cell A3 and enter the formula for calculating the profit in one of the following ways:

choices.choice: Type = Sales-Purchases and press the Enter key.
Type = then select A2, type -, then select A1 and press the Enter key.
Type = then choose Formulas Use in formula (group Defined Names) Sales , type - and then choose Formulas Use in formula (group Defined Names) Purchases and press the Enter key.

step.stepresult: In cell A3 the answer 175 appears. Selecting this cell shows you =Sales-Purchases in the formula bar. By using names you get a well readable formula.
